chapter.htmlStringContent:
The following National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) audit criteria are relevant for this CKS topic:

  • Audit criterion 1. A 2-week washout period is left after proton pump inhibitor (PPI) use before testing for Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) with a breath test or stool antigen test.
  • Audit criterion 2. Empirical full-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy is offered for 4 weeks for people with dyspepsia.
  • Audit criterion 3. All people with dyspepsia are offered H. pylori 'test and treat'.
  • Audit criterion 4. If symptoms of dyspepsia or GORD return after initial care strategies, PPI therapy is stepped down to the lowest dose needed to control symptoms.
  • Audit criterion 5. H2 receptor antagonist (H2RA) therapy is offered if there is an inadequate response to a PPI.

H. pylori testing

  • 1. H. pylori is tested for using a carbon-13 urea breath test or a stool antigen test or laboratory-based serology.
  • 2. Re-testing for H. pylori is performed using a carbon-13 urea breath test.
  • 3. Office-based serological tests are not used.

First-line H. pylori treatment

  • 4. People who test positive for H. pylori are offered a 7-day, twice-daily course of treatment with:
    • a PPI and
    • amoxicillin and
    • either clarithromycin or metronidazole.
  • 5. People who are allergic to penicillin are offered a 7-day, twice-daily course of treatment with:
    • a PPI and
    • clarithromycin and
    • metronidazole.
  • 6. People who are allergic to penicillin and who have had previous exposure to clarithromycin are offered a 7-day, twice-daily course of treatment with:
    • a PPI and
    • bismuth and
    • metronidazole and
    • tetracycline.

Second-line H. pylori treatment

  • 7. People who still have symptoms after first-line eradication treatment are offered a 7-day, twice-daily course of treatment with:
    • a PPI and
    • amoxicillin and
    • either clarithromycin or metronidazole (whichever was not used first-line).
  • 8. People who have had previous exposure to clarithromycin and metronidazole are offered a 7-day, twice-daily course of treatment with:
    • a PPI and
    • amoxicillin and
    • a quinolone or tetracycline.
  • 9. People who are allergic to penicillin and have not had previous exposure to a quinolone are offered a 7-day, twice-daily course of treatment with:
    • a PPI and 
    • metronidazole and 
    • levofloxacin.
  • 10. People who are allergic to penicillin and who have had previous exposure to a quinolone are offered:
    • a PPI and
    • bismuth and
    • metronidazole and
    • tetracycline.
  • 11. If eradication of H. pylori is not successful with second-line treatment, advice is sought from a gastroenterologist.

[NICE, 2014]
